New Records: Alex Hales returned to the England T20 team after a three-year absence and scored 86 not out in 47 balls, the highest score by an England player in a T20 World Cup semi-final.
Jos Buttler contributed 80 not out from 49 balls, forming a record-breaking 166-run partnership with Alex Hales, the highest opening stand in T20 World Cup history.
England achieved their highest score in a T20 match, with 170 runs on 24 balls, and their second-highest partnership in the format.
Key Match Events: England won the match by 10 wickets, their first in a T20 World Cup semi-final since 2007.
The match was a statement victory for England, outperforming their opponents both in batting and bowling.
Jos Buttler was praised for his leadership and key contributions, while Alex Hales was lauded for his explosive innings.
Pre-Game Insights: England's players were excited and well-prepared, with Jos Buttler setting the tone in the opening over.
Key players like Chris Jordan and Phil Salt were called up due to injuries, showcasing England's depth.
The match was a high-stakes encounter, with India having strong support in the crowd.
Post-Match Reflections: Jos Buttler emphasized the team's resilience and character, highlighting their performance as a group.
Alex Hales expressed his joy at returning to the World Cup stage and his gratitude for the opportunity to play again.
Rohit Sharma criticized India's bowling performance and acknowledged England's clinical chase.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The match was held at Adelaide Oval, one of the best venues for T20 cricket, with a 40,094-strong crowd.
The result set up a final against Pakistan, which was the first time the two teams had met in the T20 World Cup since 2007.
The victory marked a significant milestone for England, who had struggled in previous World Cup campaigns.
Others: The match was live-blogged, providing detailed updates and insights into key moments.
The outcome was a pivotal moment in the tournament, determining the final two teams in the championship.
